pros: best pro i found was leaving
cons:
This is the worst job i have ever worked at in my life. The training process was great, Dan young gave me a advert for the great place this will be to work ( i was wrong) Once you're out of the training process another thing which was good was the academy period which lasted around 3 weeks with Dharon Pitt this was also a good advert. Unfortunately this was where it ended and the emotional destruction and, blackmail and micro management started. 

If a phone call comes in and they're not going to renew because they've sold there car so, don't require the insurance, this is your fault, WHY DIDN'T YOU RENEW THEM!! If someone rings through and they've told you twice they don't want to renew, make sure you badger them and harass them and stress the customer out because that's what you're told to do. or when a customer comes through and would like to speak to a manager, good luck trying to find one who can justify why they're paid more and actually take the call over from you, you will be told to say this and say that when really the customer would like to speak to the manager, either way it's your fault for even bothering the manager whilst they have a good catch up about social lives etc. 

When you have your 15 minuet break times don't you dare go 30 seconds over it because this will result in a good talking too and making you feel as though you are a child in school. i understand and appreciate someone being late but this is a new meaning. One thing that is great is the bribery, often when the managers or senior members of the staff need a good review in order to keep there job, they'll bribe you, what with? a Kit-Cat was mine, i was so excited i couldn't wait to write about how awesome the culture and workplace was here! if you renew 15 customers in a row without using any time to breath while standing on your head you earn yourself... a TV? Money? a car? no a celebration (not the box a single celebration) 

If you have any sort of mental health, anxiety, or any emotional imbalance avoid working here as a CR. this will finish you off. They often try to promote there 4C's message which is Colleagues, Customers, Company, Community. a great message which starts with colleagues meaning it will benefit the next part and so on, its a shame they done actually do this, if you're feeling down, get back on the phone, late for work due to a car crash, get back on the phone, if your whole family is in a life threatening situation, please please just get back on the phone. if you're feeling down, depressed, suicidal and would love to go home due to you not being able to reach your maximum potential...then please go you need it ( but just expect your disciplinary on your desk tomorrow) but please go if that's what you wanna do. 

i was often asked to stay past contracted hours in order to get through the call ques, despite this not being in my contract it was expected otherwise you should say goodbye to your job. You're also bombarded with awful stat expectations, and when you've had a good day? could do better, when you've had a perfect 100% day there is very little recognition or acknowledgment for this, I'm sure a lot of people who are under this pressure want a 100% day just so they don't have to hear the same broken record about how this is all because of you, you're not doing enough you're not saying what we told you, you didn't do this you didn't do that, be prepared to speak like a robot, but please add some character and personality in there (whilst you repeat exactly what we've said and follow a script) 

There is so many things wrong here, at first i felt i could've been harsh but no this is exactly how its run, it's a schoolground mentality with the managers thinking they're the teachers and own you but life changing consequences, which is loosing your job, I'm sorry to anyone who didn't see this and now works there and to anyone who's reading this and doesn't work here..Don't.

pros: The HR team are so inadequate that I was able to be made redundant by noticing that they had not adhered to employment laws surrounding the redundancy process. Also had not honoured the reasons that they rejected my initial appeal (read: begging to be let go).
cons:
Diligenta acquired my employment by being lucky enough to convince Lloyds to TUPE transfer my department and others over to them, effectively outsourcing their work whilst still reaping the benefits of keeping us to deal with their customers. Well, those benefits I'm sure have not been worth the hassle for the affected products in Halifax Financial Services, Clerical Medical and Scottish Widows. Their "incredible" system BaNCS is dreadful, slow, not user friendly, and the opposite of intuitive. They have strict processes for every requirement which are inflexible and work to the detriment of both customer, and call handler. By having offshore servicing teams the communication within the business to get things done right just falls apart, meaning things are often done wrong several times before it is fixed. 

After moving all the Lloyds Banking Group work from Bristol to Edinburgh (which was managed absolutely atrociously) we faced redundancy or relocation to Aviva who they also work for. The redundancy announcement came roughly a week before March's lockdown at the beginning of a global pandemic, which Diligenta must be very grateful for as it stopped the immediate haemorrhaging of staff who instead reluctantly stayed for the temporary job security - myself included. I was given the old bait-and-switch when I was unluckily moved over to Aviva, as on day 2 of my training, I was then informed the REAL role I would be doing was in an entirely different department to that which I was initially informed I would go into. Working at Aviva was not convenient to me, as it meant my office was now in BS34 instead of BS1 - which as you might gather is a fairly substantial distance which ate into both my wallet (now requiring public transport) and commute time. No financial reimbursement was offered to cover these or adjusted shift times. Diligenta values nothing more than a captive work force, and so I fought my move within Diligenta rather than resigned primarily because they seemed to welcome resignations as the cheapest way of letting the demoralised staff go. 5 months after the move to Aviva I was finally free to leave with redundancy, 13 months after the original announcement and now carrying the scars of deep stress, frustration, anxiety and depression over this time. 

At every point where it felt like normality had resumed after another change for the worse within Diligenta, we were struck with a new change with further ruptured the work environment - whether that was up-skilling without increased salary (ie, more work, same pay), refusal to level out pay discrepancies, increasing staff surveillance by managers, or adding new systems to increase the already burdensome number of different logins and bureaucratic steps needed just to do something like request holiday. They even asked us to download an app which would have a disturbingly wide range of unnecessary accesses to information stored on our personal devices, in order to log our hours despite these already being visible on other systems to the necessary lines of authority.

Internal progression is practically non-existent, they won't inform you if there is a salary increase involved prior to application for some internal moves, and it is a series of tick-box interviews/cover letters which does not actually look at any track record of achievement and so means the empty vessel sounding loudest will often regurgitate enough buzzwords to tick the boxes and get the job ahead of more qualified candidates. 

The above is by no means a complete list of issues within Diligenta, but are as much as I have the energy to outline. If you have other options I would highly recommend you take them before working at Diligenta. They would probably make for an adequate first job, but to echo the words of a manager formerly at Diligenta, don't stay longer than 1-2 years because it will slowly destroy you and will not offer suitable progression or pay rises to sustain any personal growth.

pros: SBS is a great stepping stone for people who wish to further themselves within the financial industry. As my first role within the industry it has taught me a lot in my short time of being here. The atmosphere is professional but not excessive and there are plenty of laughs to be had with your colleagues. During my time here I have unfortunately had a few problems at home and I have to say that Skipton definitely aid you with out-of-office issues that may arise. As a company I feel aided by them and don't feel judged for having a life outside of the workplace.
cons: Unfortunately, the main issue with SBS as a whole is the route for progression. If you are the type of person who is a real go-getter then I would probably advise stearing away from SBS. I was told there was room for progression after reiterating the importance of this to myself many times in my interview process and since being there for a short amount of time I feel like I have already hit a very low ceiling. The problem with this is that it makes colleagues stagnate and become complacent.

pros:
I previously submitted a terrible review for BPP, after my first six months there. However, having seen the way BPP have reacted to Covid-19, plus changes in attitudes management made before the pandemic, my views have changed.

Managers reacted really well to criticism from the team, changing the way in which they worked with us, and have consulted with us much better than before.

During the pandemic, BPP allowed all staff to work from home without question, except for the tiny minority they had to furlough until September 2020. It also looks like BPP will be offering much more flexibility in terms of working from home, which is excellent for members of staff like I, who have difficulties with mental health, and other health conditions, who have actually had a very positive experience working from home since March.

Although there are obvious, fair criticisms from a minority of students, BPP has dealt with the impact of the pandemic quite well, and has made appropriate changes to working practice. For example, all exams have been moved online until at least August 2021, which has given students some certainty. Additionally, BPP are running Covid-secure face to face exams for those who cannot use our online exam platform, which is excellent.
cons:
Some urgent work can be sprung on staff without any fair warning.

Would like to be given more certainty about working from home - not just a promise of more flexibility.

pros:
Some of the core values Unity tries to embrace are "Best Idea Wins", "Go Bold" and "In It Together". I've worked at many companies whose values are allegedly good, but don't actually take action on them. In contrast, Unity seems to really invest in these ideas. They deliver Active Listening training to leaders. They have a whole range of social events. They even have an entire Wellbeing team dedicated to running clubs and socials, sending gifts, and so on (so these responsibilities don't fall on the shoulders of people who are juggling this with other work)! They also have several Employee Resource Groups for people in marginalised groups (like a BIPOC one, an LGBTQ+ one, a women's ERG, and so on). Sustainability is also a core concern, with much discussion and events happening around that.

Every team is managed differently, so your experience may vary, but I am given lots of freedom to shape my job to fit myself, rather than change myself to fit the role. I can explore different technologies, collaborate across the organisation, and get involved in a wide variety of work.

The work is interesting and generously compensated (both in terms of salary and holiday allowance); the people are brilliantly smart, talented, and excellent listeners; and the technology is cutting-edge and exciting to work with. It's the most positive and inspirational workplace I've ever had the pleasure of working at.
cons:
Sometimes too many meetings, especially during the pandemic (as it's a big organisation).

If you're not from a corporate background, the jargon can be off-putting. There is a jargon glossary though!

Many different systems for different tasks. Not a huge problem, just a lot to learn when you first arrive.

Sometimes things are moving so fast, it feels as if we haven't finished one product/solution before we're working on or shipping the next one, which can damage credibility with users (e.g. if something ships with bugs)

pros: Easy role, good work banter and a good social circle of colleagues. Lots of young, energetic employees, central location in the Arndale Tower.
cons: The progression is largely determined by where you sit on the L B G T diversity template that has permeated this company's HR department above every other facet of common sense and consideration on how to run a HR function. If you arent flying that particular flag, you will be ignored and passed over with predictable & sickening regularity. Pay is ok for the basic work you do but it's not a career - if you want to earn less than £24k for the rest of your life this is a good place to stay. Perhaps the worse part of this job is management. They are mainly comprised of failed HR managers who werent industrious enough to get through their CIPD exams so they compensate by dragging junior members of staff into attendance & performance review meetings at every single opportunity. The phrase "managed out" springs to mind - any infraction for lateness (even if evidenced with events beyond your control) is punished with meeting after meeting, followed by gleeful team leaders savouring any opportunity to punish team members for such diverse reasons as childcare, bereavement, illness, etc, followed by further back to back meetings designed to undermine, torment & eventually bin employees off rather than solve problems and look at reasonable adjustments. For a HR department, they sure do make it up as they go along. The only real consistency I saw in this role is that backbiting, underhanded informing on your colleagues was encouraged and rewarded by manager's favouritism. All in this makes for a very negative, toxic and distasteful workplace.

And on top of it the Team Leader always laughed at people's cases and some her colleagues just gather around her desk and doing the same which I thought was very disrespectful, also what baffles me is that I supposedly done something wrong so I was told not to return and not one word was said to me at the time so of course I didn't have the opportunity to give explanation or defend myself, ok I weren't a permanent staff member- however yet if I wanted time off I had to give a weeks notice - how does that work out exactly ? Story is, aside from that mysterious mistake I supposedly made I was not familiar or too much understanding with the work - all I did was what I was trained to do and I did ask what else or if anything else I be trained on and did ask if there is anything someone can teach me, answer was either 'No' or 'I don't know' - lack of communication and not being straight with people.

cons: The induction steps and the process could have been managed in a more organised way. i.e. Having all the IT equipment organised and connected in one go - or more could have been arranged in advance to avoid many calls with IT. The onboarding trainings could be managed through a system - for ex. an employee profile rather than excel sheet and etc. It would be good to remove everything that looks and feels old school to lead by example in such a fast paced and progressive business world.

pros: Move dept every 2 to 3 years which keeps the job fresh.  In turn this means a frequent turnover of managers.  You're lucky if you manage to get a decent manager but expect them to move on and fast!  Middle managers are pretty useless many of which have no management experience and no training so you find yourself managed by people who don't have a clue.  On the plus you do get a pension, sick pay and decent maternity package.
cons: Not interested in support grades. Unfair treatment.  Expectation to work much longer hours for zero compensation either money or time off in lieu. Bad performance often not tackled which leaves the hard workers often carrying  a heavier workload.  Training inadequate.  Systems of working often change and employees not consulted.  Staff welfare generally not a concern the organisation says all the right things to tick the right boxes but in practice their staff welfare is pretty non existent.

pros: Accumulated stock awards are attractive if you are at the Principal Engineer/Director level
cons:
Two years on from my departure and I still struggle to identify anything remotely positive about Cisco beyond staying for share options. Continual, stealth headcount reductions after each quarter's results have gradually removed those with the energy and creativity that Cisco desperately needs to reinvent itself. For those early-in-career, I'm not convinced that having Cisco on the resume/CV helps. My experience is it can hinder you when applying to new roles as you are tarred with having worked in a slow-moving, behemoth company rather than a fast-moving agile start-up.

Let's face it - this is a company that should have owned the whole videoconference market in the wake of COVID-19 via WebEx yet it is Zoom that has stolen both the zeitgeist and the market. That should be enough for the Board to call for Chuck to step down and for them to bring in a visionary technology leader rather than yet another senior salesperson with a strategy that only looks 2 quarters out in a vain attempt to keep Wall St happy...

pros:
Brand name
Project exposure
Security and stability a large firm brings
Starting to clear out the sub par male, pale, stale leadership
cons:
Pay is awful
Bonus is embarrassing 
L&D opportunities aren’t there - unless you want to do CIMA or ACA there’s no chance of anything meaningful, no masters sponsorship etc
This is no exaggeration, five - ten years behind on the digital agenda. Utterly clueless
Fragmented - partners scrapping for revenue and status. 
Partners are generally nothing special, very few intellectual powerhouses in the firm, mostly sales focussed individuals that were fortuitously aligned to a big-revenue client earlier in their career 
Some partners genuinely view the world in terms of ‘winners’ and ‘losers’ - it would be cringe if it wasn’t so toxic 
Politics are unbearable 
If a partner takes a dislike to you, you may as well resign, seen many careers ruined
Promotions are a joke - there are people who are performing for 1 yr + at the grade above and still cannot get promoted. There have been people selling a lot of work that still get turned down
When you do go for promotion you are put through an interview process and have to provide a business case at even Manager level (something you literally cannot control, given it depends on the work you are aligned to)
Systems are so outdated and lead to a ton of admin
Very much a conform or leave agenda in terms of culture
D&I initiatives more oriented towards protecting partners from embarrassing headlines than actually addressing D&I issues - there have been no substantial policy changes in recruitment for example. 
The consulting practice is basically an advisory firm - generalists do not progress. If you want to progress you need to specialise in a certain, very specific area, which kind of defeats the reason why many people go into consulting in the first place. 
Quality of work is painfully variable - I’ve seen some work that can rival MBB and other work that is so poor I’m almost embarrassed for the client receiving it

pros:
Some nice people to work with
Good pension scheme
cons:
The culture is really not what it used to be.
Since the new management took over, it has all gone downhill.
Extremely long hours, no work life balance, senior managers and directors email and message at all hours (earliest I got was 5am and latest midnight), even though they claim that ‘they are happy to discuss flexible working’. Flexible meaning, you have to be flexible and around.
Career progression is based on favouritism, or knowing that if they don’t promote, people will definitely leave, and people agreeing to get promotions without a raise with a semi-promise that they will get something the next year. Don’t ask for a raise, you won’t get it and you will end up 
 in their bad books.
The pay is low, the benefits are not great, except for the pension which is pretty good.
Don’t expect bonuses to be of much worth, and they stress that they are discretionary.
They don’t actually care about well-being, people being overworked and underpaid. It’s extremely difficult to get in lieu time for the extra time worked even if your manager knows that you have worked 10-12 hour days.
If you do decide to join, treat this as a temporary gig, most people leave after a couple of years, primarily the ones who are good at their jobs. The rest get promoted to fill roles that are incapable of doing.
Also, forget about training, there is literally no budget for that. They have an internal team who (bless them) do the best they can, but clearly are not going to be able to offer specialised training in areas outside the core bank roles.
Don’t make the same mistake I made to buy into the ‘culture’, it’s at best a facade. Who is left is some senior directors who have no clue what they are doing and destroying anything good left from the culture.

- Stress vs Benefits is unreasonable. Consulting in stressful. For some reason it can be more stressful in Accenture due to some particular managers / senior managers. I wasn't lucky and all my projects had at least one regularly screaming team member.

- Nearly not enough projects for all hires. I understand the churn rate in consulting, but firing people because they cannot find a project, while being a junior team member is questionable.

pros:
(Review of Consulting role)
- Lots of opportunities to work in different industries and types of project without having to change employer every time
- Motivated people
- People are driven to get stuff done
- If you want to follow a particular interest e.g set up a community or run a knowledge sharing session, usually fairly straightforward to get funding/support
- Staff are rewarded well e.g socials, bonus, benefits
- There's money for training
cons:
- A lot of projects expect long hours and big commitment - therefore, can be poor work/life balance
- Everything comes down to profit in the end
- Can be forced into roles that might not be the right for you if you end up in the wrong place at the wrong time
- Difficult to progress beyond Manager if you're more client delivery focused than sales/business growth focused

pros:
The work is genuinely rewarding. 

The Service Users were occasionally challenging but usually great fun to be around. 

Most of the staff I worked with are lovely, caring and diligent people, and I hope to stay in contact with several of them. 

The grounds were (once upon a time) beautiful.
cons:
Management - the attitude of some individuals stinks (others were very supportive). 

Communications are abysmal - top-down, one-way and inefficient beyond nightmare status. Newsletters, clearly designed for online distribution, are printed out and circulated behind a signing sheet. None of the houses had computers or printers, so everything was done on paper, and if you ran out of any forms on the weekend you spent more time trying to scrounge forms from other houses than filling the damn things in. When they eventually find their way 'upstairs' they are typed in to a computer and then apparently forgotten about.

Investment is awful. The fabric of the building and grounds were very poorly maintained - there were innumerable safety issues that we had to live with, such as broken lighting, doors hanging off of hinges, damaged door locks and self-closers, and constant issues with laundry and cooking equipment. The grounds have been let go to wrack and ruin.

The food prepared for the service users is sometimes embarrassing. Crappy ingredients coupled with weird menus and bizarre recipes put together by people whose skill level ran from 'chef' standard to worse than '1st-year-at-Uni'. The site deals with eating disorders but I never met anyone with any form of qualification as a nutritionist or dietician.

Career and professional development is treated as a burden. If you find a course to expand upon a special interest don't even waste your time applying for support or funding.

The worst thing is that the site manager at my location couldn't be bothered to talk to staff. When she does she is often rude. When she visits the service users she is often rude to them and nearly always provokes some kind of incident for the Support Workers to manage after she's gone. And she seems totally oblivious to her purpose (to care for her service users) and her biggest business issue (attracting and retaining staff).

Like so many other places in care, Trust, Loyalty and Flexibility are one-way streets.

pros: Working for the company in Knightsbridge was an amazing experience. Colleagues and managers were lovely, but that also depends on which department you're in. I was lucky to be in a nice environment with friendly people who were always there to give support as I was new. Unfortunately, I was only at this location for a short period of time.
cons: Working at the Harrods at Heathrow airport was an overall bad experience for me. The managers were the main problem, never there for support, only there to find something to vent their anger at. The biggest problem was the toxic environment. If you weren't a part of their clique then that's it. One of my colleagues, who I had an argument with, was very close to a certain member of management and basically played it their way to make my life hell when I was there. Things at Heathrow get overlooked as the HR is probably already too busy with the main London store, therefore serious issues that need to be addressed at Heathrow get brushed under the rug.

I left in 2017 on approx £22/£23k per year year into the same role at another company on £35k which, by the end of the year I joined, had increased to £40k. I also felt there was a degree of cronyism that you only got ahead of you knew the right people. I always asked for development but was passed up time and again, mainly I believe due to not being great at their interview style. I always felt like my face didn’t fit and since leaving have had 2 promotions. Maybe I wasn’t ready at the time but I felt like I was sisyphus pushing the rock endlessly up a hill with no let up or reward!

pros: Holidays, Bupa which you will need!
cons:
Treat you awfully. If you want the hour lunch your supposed to get you’ll be home for 9pm bearing in mind you have to get to your first job for 8. All they are bothered about is sales RAF they pester you constantly and instead of praising someone when they do well they bash everyone else round the head saying look how good this guy is and then the next month it will be some other guy. No flexibility, no progression unless your best mates with higher managers. Corrupt through and through. Oh and every customer survey that comes back bad because of the shocking customer call centre - that’s your fault. They give you about 41 minutes a job when they know it’s impossible to do everything on their Audits yet do nothing about it. About 8 people have left in the last month some with years and years of service and no more then a see you later. Oh and they did secret shoppers where they were hiding in peoples houses and taking photos of us without permission and posting them laughing. 
So if you want a job with no progression, where you work an hour a day for free and be hassled for sales when you are technician then go for it!

pros:
Career Opportunities & D&I - Focused on doing the right thing and ensuring everyone is regularly offered and takes advantage of mandatory trained on critical topics such as Security, Quality, Diversity and Inclusion. Provide access to multiple online and webinar trainings to develop their People.
Technology - a huge variety of tech' and a driving movement towards Cloud offering yet more opportunities from Salesforce, .Net, C#, Java, JS, Angular, REST, API's, Selenium etc.
Comp' & Benefits - tangible bonus system that you have control over a proportion of making personal responsibility a key attribute of their employees. This sparks people on to giving their best. I could go on for days.
Culture and Values - Satisfaction surveys where actions is promptly taken. Sensible 
Senior Management - Switched on, smart, capable and care about their people (not resources). Fully recognise the value we all bring and are appreciative at every opportunity. Covid - absolutely outstanding in caring for staff health and wellbeing, avoided Furlough, protected jobs, considerate of everyone's situation and been fantastic with comm's, updates, flexibility and resources such as free Mindfulness app.
Work/Life Balance - Incredibly supportive of this with flexible hours, open conversations on concerns in this area and help always available from managers to juggle the Covid new world we live in. Additionally (unprompted) offered 3 additional wellbeing days off on top of annual leave to spend on caring for ourselves so we bring our best selves to work every day.

pros: Immediate team were good people, friendly and helpful
cons: They market roles and recruit people from / looking to work in an HR focussed role but are pushing the function increasingly into customer services / call centre with very little HR work or progression. I've heard of people quitting in their first week due to realising the role was not as advertised. Genuinely awful systems (the worst i've ever worked with by far) and processes that make the team's work a lot harder and unrewarding than it should or needs to be. High turnover and everyone i spoke to in the team seems to want to leave due to being pushed away from HR and into essentially customer services. Very high volume of work with not enough people or experience to get it done, the work itself is unrewarding but stressful due to volume & SLA pressure. Performance measured only via SLA's which keep ticking during non working hours / weekends due to the ineffective system used, and don't really reflect the work being done. Focus is just get the cases closed before they breach SLA, whatever it's regarding. No benefits to working there, everything statutory. Almost no training provided; some processes explained in first few days but then largely left to figure it out on your own whilst the SLA's tick away and cases pile up. When resigning, you don't even get a letter emailed / posted acknowleding your resignation, that's how little you mean to the company, you are literally just a machine to churn out case after case before SLA is breached. Does not provide any relevant HR experience for future progression

pros:
I worked while I was a uni student and worked at a store very close to my university, which meant that during university holidays, the store was very quiet. This meant that I was not needed during the Christmas and Summer holiday periods which was incredible to find in a job.
You can work with really great people, I made a lot of friends here.
The business of each shift is pretty easy to judge depending on the day of the week it is.
cons:
I originally started as a Checkout Assistant but then became a Supervisor about a year into the job. There isn't any pay rise with this even though the amount of knowledge required, responsibility and pressure is a lot higher. This is because Supervisors don't technically exist in Sainsbury's anymore as everyone is meant to be trained to the same level, but nobody can be bothered to train everyone up that much and some people are not interested in having to learn so much.
On my last paycheck, they paid me £400 less than I was meant to receive, but they had locked me out of the HR centre where I would be able to view my paycheck as I was leaving. I was advised to call the HR department but they literally NEVER answer the phone. Only after a manager actually dealt with it did I get paid any more, but I was still paid £30 short. Getting hugely underpaid on your last month's paycheck is a really common issue, and Sainsbury's make it very difficult for you to chase up anyone about it. So just be prepped for that as it was a horrible note to leave on.

pros: I've found Barratt to be a genuinely considerate employer - they really care about making you be the best you can be. If you put the work in, they will support you to reach your potential. I think the way they supported their staff during the coronavirus crisis was a true testament to this. Health and safety came first, and they made sure everyone received their normal pay if on furlough, and then brought everyone back by the end of June. It's also great to work for a company that absolutely wants to do the right thing. I think this is led from the top by excellent leadership from David Thomas, who beyond being a genuinely nice person is committed to supporting charities and local communities. It's great to be able to feel proud of the company you work for.
cons: I don't really have anything negative to say about Barratt. I've been lucky enough to have had excellent managers and opportunities throughout my time at Barratt and I think this has guided my experience.

pros:

pros:
Recent leadership changes (last year) are really prioritising growth.
Very accomodating and flexible place to work.
Amazingly passionate technical teams who LOVE the technologies they work with.
cons:
1. Bureaucracy, bureaucracy, bureaucracy! Totallly siloed business restricts the innovation that teams can actually perform. Business processes are so opaque and varied across business units and even manager to manager.
2. Slow to act on climate goals - employees branded "idealists" for asking climate-related questions in CEO ask-me-anythings.
3. Had to essentially get another job offer on the table to get an overdue promotion. Requests were ignored despite having ~8 senior employee support statements. Ended up happening in the middle of a bad quarter, which gave leadership the appearance of being shocked and desperate. 
4. So many people! IBM has one of the biggest workforces in the world - and isn't moving fast as a result. Definitely adopted Agile (in some teams) but not Lean!
5. Often hard to trace through from corporate strategy to your functional role... but this is getting better with concerted effort from leadership sharing strategy.
6. Very few opportunities for progression in the UK in comparison to the rest of the world - and no opportunity to relocate.

pros:
I started on a temp contract back in April 2010 (I was only 19!), I was made Perm in the October 2010. Since then I've had ample opportunity to move around experiencing many different teams. Since you learn many transferable skills, you can always move around to strengthen your core skills, my friends have all been on that journey and then suddenly you land yourself in a team that you just know fits perfectly for you. I've now been in Commercial for 3 1/2 years and wow it's sometimes challenging, but it's a rewarding challenge. 

I've had the opportunity to complete educational courses and for this I'm glad I can say I continue to work for UU. 

Our Director is very approachable and so is every member of management including senior management, this also including the CEO. They all say hello in passing. This makes working for UU feel more like a family, I've gained many friends for life. On a night together we always have a time to talk about what's going on in work. This tells me that we all enjoy it, not many people want to talk work whilst out socialising (Pre-Covid!).

Overall, if you want a job for life sign up for the jobs page. All my friends always ask me how to join and some have been successful, keep trying and like I said with it's diverse work force a perfect job will soon appear.
cons: Cons..There are no cons. I think anyone can say something about work they dis-like but these out way the Pro's!

pros:
- £9.30/hr is pretty good, all things considered
- 10% colleague discount throughout the year, goes up to 15% every payday weekend
- Generous breaks
- Take colleague health concerns seriously
cons:
- Pay is not worth the hassle you get from both customers and management, and occasionally your own colleagues
- Yearly limit of £1,000 colleague discount
- Breaks begin the moment you leave your department. If a customer needs your help for the full length of your break, then tough, and if you're even a minute late, team support reports you to management 
- Full of jobsworths. Some managers lack any empathy or people skills, while colleagues and team leaders will screw you over if it means getting a foot up the ladder.
- Sickness policy does not take any overtime you do into account, meaning that one sick day can have a huge impact on your attendance record if you're only contracted to one or two days a week
- Expect you to be fully flexible for them but are very rarely flexible for you outside of their legal obligations
- You don't get to decide your own availability
- Nepotism is rampant. Cliques everywhere. To get anywhere at all, you need to be best pals with management first
- Some managers will undermine you when dealing with difficult customers
- Broken checkouts/systems take months to get repaired or replaced
- Absolutely zero trust placed in staff

“Guest satisfaction is not a priority, the management is only focused on numbers therefore the team is constantly working under pressure. No matter how hard the day has been, if you don't bring them numbers you are taken to the small office and shouted for half an hour (after your shift has ended). 
 If you are not liked by someone within the management team, you are taken to this small office everyday and told off, until you give up and resign.” It is also true that only poor skilled people are getting promoted and their only skill is to “report” and being the bad cop of the situation. Management is really bad and Front Office managers do not want to work on Weekends, which gives a horrible example and also do not care about your wellbeing. Andaz London Liverpool Street DOES NOT respect the Hytt company motto: we care for people so they can be their best, that is an absolute joke in their case.

pros: A fantastic range of training and support is frequently provided to every member of the team. As someone who is completely new to the recruitment industry, I have felt fully supported in both my development and practices via the means of training seminars and peer support. Included within this, have been numerous 1:1 weekly support meetings with experts in the field. These meets have allowed me to share positive developments and areas to improve, to where my mentors have been yet again able to support me in bettering my professional practices. The teams I work with currently are a fantastic range of people, each stemming from different roles or backgrounds. They have truly made me feel included, supported and most importantly enjoy this role even more. Randstad as a whole, has an entire unity feel. Whether I need to discuss things with the branch manager, regional manager or even the CEO, I can contact anyone of these people in different positions of authority, and I know they will come back to me with a welcoming and supportive manor.
cons: There isn't anything I could really say about this company or my role in a negative way. However, if you are to join Randstad, I would recommend that your IT skills are up to date/efficient, as Administration plays a great role within a recruitment position.

pros: Can do overtime if needed
cons: Honestly, whenever I read reviews like this I always thought oh they’re just bitter or had a bad experience. But I started working there July 2020 in a group of 20-30 and I believe only 3 people have stayed, those people I have spoken to and they are looking for other jobs currently. They have a huge high turnover of staff and they are very aware of it. I have never worked in such a horrid toxic environment. Middle management staff telling you to hurry up when you have to ask to go to the toilet in a group chat of 500 people as you work from home. They are so rude and vile to everyone. The job itself is hideous. It’s a boring easy job which is fair enough but they don’t tell you that you just get abused on the phone 7 hours a day everyday. I’ve never experience mental health issues before since this job. You receive absolutely NO support and even if you ask for help or to solely do emails (as you have to do them as well as calls) they take you off calls for a few mins until the horrid middle management start pushing calls through again. I cannot stress enough how you should avoid to work for this company. Everyone I have spoken to who work for this company has had the exact same experience as me. It is not worth the minimum wage. Even after leaving I have had so many problems with my last pay and had staff members literally laugh on the phone whilst almost in tears trying to sort it out. They are so useless and unhelpful. Whilst working their i received so many complaints from other employees regarding the bully culture and horrible hr team who ignore all emails

pros:
Legal and general is like an old Bentley. comfy with a powerful engine, but a lot of weight to shift. It’ll be nice to be in, but 0-60 will take 20 years.

Big org, diverse environments to work in. Wonderful people and changeable pace, lots of best practice to learn from. It’s highly regulated, so you see what good looks like every day.

I enjoyed all the teams I worked with. Loved the different divisions and completely different operating models. I worked in many locations. Kingswood, Cardiff, Brighton, London and even regional partners.

I started as a Senior Finance Analyst and progressed to management fairly fast in 2 years. Being a business partner to multiple divisions across a few entities has given me some great insights into operating models, having some challenging projects to work on commercially and financially.

It’s hard to make a difference there; to have a voice and face. I managed to, but had to slog and really push change to sell it more widely. Shouldn’t be so hard to make things better.
cons:
In finance it’s hard to get up the chain into senior leadership there and regardless of skills, shining reviews, outstanding performance etc, restructures set people back year in year out, which is pretty awful; there’s a lot of competition from Group finance who are markedly more visible to leadership, so opportunities there is fairly static and staid. You just have to see how long people stay “finance managers” before becoming heads. Some 10 years, (reshuffled, relearn, reestablish, outperform, only to be displaced due to restructure to start all over again). When that happens to the superstars, you know there are issues. 

It’s poorly paid as well. For a FTSE it’s shocking. It’s not until you leave that you realise how bad the pay grades are. Pigeonholed in Finance, in middle management, during the most important time of your career to diversify and grow.

I left, took a seniority cut in different sector, (a charity at that) earning £10,000k more + 20% bonus, was promoted in new role within 6 months. Within a year promoted again as a head in FP&A and Business Improvements. So after pouring heart and soul into that company, to earn peanuts for 7 years at L&G as a high performing Finance Manager, within 4 years of leaving, 2 companies later, I’m now an Operations Director, with loads more experience and on track for a fulfilling career doing what I do best.

I interviewed at legal and general a couple years back in Hove. Unsurprisingly it seemed the world had stopped going back there. Even the tech and ways of working were the same. (Which filled me with dread given how much the world had advanced with MS Teams/interview techniques/tablets etc) I realised it’s a leviathan and will take tens of years to change process and senior leadership. It’s stifling. Systems are still same, ways of working are backward and unsurprisingly, I found myself questioning why I’d want to work there again after tasting what “excellent” looks and feels like.

Quite stark. That industry really grabs a person and pins them in place.

Training opportunities and courses are archaic too.

pros:
I did have my reservations about joining given the fact that they are always looking for drivers, however I really do enjoy the challenges and variety this job brings. Doing store deliveries is hard work at times when you have a manual pump truck to take off the load, however this is balanced out when you have stores where you just open the curtains and let the FLT Driver get on with it. Most of the staff at the stores are great to work with, all you need to do is be friendly and helpful which makes their day. The depot colleagues and drivers are also great to work with, most are 
friendly. I enjoy it here, and having new Scanias to drive makes the job better! Despite it being hard work, the job is secure which is important to me.
cons: The pay should reflect the work we do considering the amount of pallets we move per day, and the weight of some exceed a tonne. No overtime is paid unless you work an additional day. Breaks are unpaid (which I totally disagree with considering we are still responsible for the truck and load) and no company sick pay.

pros: Base Pay is not bad though bonus scheme is farce. Nice enough colleagues. Training system is very good, but when you actually seek resource to go and win some business its not available and the process is dire.
cons: Leadership have clearly lost the plot, obsessed with trying to push Hybrid Cloud when the horse has bolted and already several valleys away with hyperscale providers. Internal process is shocking using lotus notes and Atlas, having to use a password t log in repeatedly to the same applications. Internal sales process is painful and the admin cost to get any sale out of the door is a joke. Not prepared to take people of fee earning work to develop decent bids so you end up with a bench of staff not skilled in the areas you actually need, so you lose the bid. No competitive targets being hit because of this as the A Team is never available and at best you get the C or D team. Management obsess about the current QTR whilst walking towards a cliff edge as no new work being won, But most don't care as will move on promotion or retire with bonus from core work. More obsessed with measuring diversity than addressing the real problems that need real investment like decent CRM and basic email system that works.

pros:
Good salary
Employee car discount
Decent maternity leave
cons:
You’re typically left to fend for yourself as a new starter/lower level employee. There isn’t much of teamwork that goes on inter-department. Everyone is protective of their bit of work. Tasks are assigned based on who’s mates with who (especially when redundancies are around the corner to protect themselves). 

Very awful culture of ‘I’ve been here longer hence know better’. Hence absolutely no room for new ideas and worse still an old boys club that’s impossible to break into. This is now a problem in the D grades level (now that the structure is being flattened).

Lots of indirect discrimination at lower grades as well.

pros: None - I’d give this 0 stars if I could
cons: DWF is the worst place I’ve ever worked. Please save your mental health by not working here. I got no training when I started, just left to do my own thing! Then months down the line my manager bullied me everyday for getting things wrong. I made it clear in the interview with them that I didn’t know loads about credit hire and that I’ve only ever done claimant work and not defendant. My manager knew this as he’s the one who interviewed me and gave me the job! He used to bully me so much. He used to make me feel so bad about getting things wrong, and never used to help me. He used to say ‘I have to think for myself’ - yet I said I was struggling with certain things and he never helped. He was constantly bullying me to the point that I got so depressed I had to have 6 weeks off work due to my mental health and multiple doctors appointments and notes! HR and my manager did a meeting with me whilst I was off claiming ‘they are here for me’ and as soon as I went back, my manager asked why I was off and he laughed at me! And told me ‘it’s just part of the job’ - it’s part of the job to be depressed and bullied by your manager? I don’t think so. This place is a joke. I complained about him and how he treated me and he just got away with it. No investigation into it or anything. My manager then had to the cheek to tell me I’m asking too many questions! Yet if I got the training I needed this wouldn’t have been the case! I’m asking too many questions? Would you rather me constantly get it wrong? What a joke. The place is laughable. Please save yourselves from this place. My mental health was one of the worst it’s ever been due to how I was treated here and they didn’t care. No investigation into him so I had no other choice but to leave. 3 months down the line after me leaving, they are saying I owe them money. They’ve changed this amount 3 times now. This place can’t be trusted. The management get away with bullying their staff, hence why they never actually take any of the job adverts down because their turnover is so high. There’s so much I could say about this place but I’d be here all day! All this for minimum wage too. Don’t put yourself through it. I regret doing it and so will you.

pros: They allow you to go home, unlike prison
cons: No work life balance, if you hate your family, pets, house or free time, then work at the EMC Wolverhampton. You get to be in work for 8 hours to the second, with the threat of a 3 hour extension or a Saturday with just a couple of hours notice, with shift work it also makes you so fatigued to do anything with the little time you do get off. If your lucky enough to work in machining you get the added bonus of excessive noise, minimum 85db plus and a sickly choking vapour of atomised oil in the air. Management have yet to grasp the concept that there is a word called 'no' to the bosses above them, though they dish it out unsparingly when asking for favours like time off to look after a sick child or dying relative. Covid does not exist at JLR and if you are stupid enough to catch it, then you are disciplined for threatening the profits the company are desperate to make.

pros: The people on my team were wonderful, and I’ve made friends for life - we bonded over how awful the job was and the relief after we left.
cons:
This is toxic, toxic environment for Technical Support Advisors. Do not be tempted to take this role if offered. It will grind you down in a way I didn’t know a job could. I would challenge you to find a single happy employee in this role, as every colleague of mine has either left due to the working environment, or has been on long term sick with stress caused by the job.

The training is based more on how to use the software, rather than fixing issues which is 90% of the calls you take. The problems continue when you get onto Gradbay - they use a glide path system where targets become increasingly difficult week by week, until they become impossible. Unrealistic targets for Adherence, handle time, CSAT, after call work, as well as many more stats are used as a rod to beat you with. The culture at Sage is nothing short of abusive and cruel. Staff retention is GradBay is a disaster, with good reason.

Even managers are miserable, most likely due to being pressured by THEIR managers to get impossible results from a team with rock bottom morale. The hyper critical coaching style and micromanagement makes you feel like you’re completely useless if you’re not generating revenue for them on every call or pushing ‘self serve’ to paying customers. The intense focus is always on getting through as many calls as possible and to generate as many sales leads as possible means that you cannot deliver customer service and tech support to increasingly angry customers who are paying for the privilege of calling. My day would begin with tears and genuine panic attacks as I joined my morning huddle, which came to feel like a ‘name and shame’ opportunity for those who had ‘let the team down’ by taking too long handling calls, and those hadn’t met their sales targets the previous day.

Abuse from customers - screaming, swearing, personal remarks about your intelligence and personality - is not only tolerated, but the dedicated Customer Complaints team would rather lay the blame on the technician for ‘not taking control of the call’ and refuse to send out warning letters to repeatedly abusive customers. Hanging up on a screaming, abusive customer is classed as ‘call avoidance’ so will land you in hot water.

The ‘internal channels’ for reporting problems that are so often mentioned in by Sage in their Glassdoor responses are non-existent. I’m not sure exactly what I would even say on them if they did exist - Sage has a culture problem. These issues aren’t something that can be fixed by putting a comment in a suggestion box.

pros: Will know to AVOID in the future!
cons:
Absolutely disgraceful agency! Never came across anything like it. I have used many agencies before this but with no issues. Discriminatory practices where unwilling to facilitate any reasonable adjustments, especially for Mental Health. After telephone interview took place was left in limbo for over a month with no email correspondence to confirm job offer. 

Received text messages from the original person from the Head Office, who interviewed me as she refused to pick up her phone? She used Covid as an excuse for texting in an unprofessional manner. It’s only when I googled the job role that I was able to seek out the nominated person, from the local branch, for the job role. 

Once started in the role, discovered there was no job security whatsoever. This was both for the length of the job and the daily duties as well. Was told by the employer, who was a government body, that they cannot tell me what the job involves because it’s a secret and they would have to take it day by day?! No contact from the agency after handed in notice. Did not even receive a courtesy email to acknowledge my resignation but still received chain emails from their email address. Wrong leaving date put on P45 in spite. 

Unprofessional and would not recommend. What a waste of time! HMRC were helpful in swiftly arranging collection of IT equipment. That is the only positive I can say about HMRC.

pros: At Exec level in the company there is a real desire to change the culture of the company. There has been a great focus on diversity and inclusion, mental health support and management training. The support provided to employees during the pandemic has been exceptional. The company is forward looking and has started to focus more on new technologies, digitisation and managed service. Colt's employees are very customer focussed and there appears to be an exciting future for Colt.
cons: There are limited opportunities for personal growth and career development for experienced people. In spite of the excellent management training and a real focus on cultural change at ELT level (including diversity and inclusion) the messages are not filtering down to the managers and past behaviours are still evident. In addition, the day to day pace is frequently exhausting for the operational teams and the amount of change in the business means there is a high level of stress . Unfortunately there are also some small pockets where due to the stress some bullying behaviour is creeping in. There also appear to be many people in "supporting" roles who don't seem to have very much to do can make it difficult for operational people.

When people could work from home, they were told to come in regardless, even before goverment said to do so. and would lie as an excuse to something you couldn't do from home, even with compromise it wasn't good enough,.Will treat you differently to another admin in same department, social distancing didn't exist there, we were told to social distance, which I did, but then managers would fill small offices with about 15 staff. 

- compulsive liars, tell you something, or forge emails to blackmail you, or risk your safety. (Covid) 

-within a matter of months I went from a bubbly individual, who enjoyed their role, to someone with work related mental health issues, which has still left me with issues with confidence and paranoia (e.g they lied and made you feel there was make believe issues)

-Worse management skills ever, you mention mental health they then make it worse, by belittling you in front of others. any new 'processes' are left to the last minute with next to no training, and then told off for not following process.

-ever changing process, tell you one thing, next thing got to do it another way. genuinely this can be a monthly change, if someone from another department decides they dont want a part of their job, expect them to load that extra work onto you, whilst the other member does less work. but only if your face fits, if you don't like a side to your job, you can't load it onto someone else if your face doesn't fit.

-absolutely no way what so ever to progress in the company, well unless you're well liked regardless of your skill set. I was well liked for a while, until I raised health and safety concerns. 

-non managers walk round like they are managers, only because they are friends with a manager. 

-Belittled in front of senior manager who said they would help and support, yet doesn't help and support, you mention grievances and they encourage you not to do so because 'grievances don't get you anywhere'

-When you finally have a break down and get signed off sick, expect occupational health to phone you, which is great, but then say they will check in every 2 weeks, then never hear from them ever again. 

-Expect a annual redundancy rumour to do the rounds. redundancies were happening every year I worked there apart from one, but if you like living on the edge it's perfect.

-Literally no overtime, no incentives, expect them to squeeze every last bit of life out of you mentally, you may have a good few years, but expect a sudden shift, and watch them all turn against you. (this isn't just personal, although it sounds it, there have been many people who have left or had issues with any issue there, this is not a bias review) 

-oh and one last thing, even when you are gone, and the manager knows it was caused by their behaviour, they just do the same to someone else. 

think that's scratched the surface, I have kept evidence for my own records, emails, texts, etc, and am seeking legal advice, clearly I was constructively dismissed.

pros: Next values are truly amazing. its a shame it does not run through out. in the HQ there is a division. company culture in the main HQ is incredible. within the company any body who works in the contact centre are seen as idiots due to the fact the follish are in leadership position. if you're good at sucking up but not good at your job you will be fine you can work your way up. if youre good at what you do, its a simple job make sure to use this amazing stepping stone to move on to the next stage of career. people who stay long get corrupted by a foolish mindset. dont be that person come in use the stepping stone and move on.
cons:
Terrible management who have no idea. next as a whole are amazing. It's a shame its not a meritocracy based atmosphere in the contact centre. theres people with no clue in leadership positions who really don't know how to do their job.(best part they boast about how they don't need to know whats going on as long as they can manage people) constant change in management because of blame culture and no one can do their job. its sad to see advisors get the slack for management error.

they speak about a coaching culture, but the team managers are terrible at this aspect they are overloaded with work bless them yet they don't even know answers to simple queries or even know basics of teaching and coaching.

great place to learn how not to run a department and take the advice to the next step in career. 

 hopefully one day the CEO realises their company was built on customer service and takes a big look into what they want in management oppose to what they actually have. they are in for a rude awakening.

pros:
The Marsden has an excellent continuing professional development programme, with lectures once a month. It seemed to be mostly for biomedical scientists (and I am not a biomedical scientist by training), however my manager encouraged me to go along too in order to continue learning. In addition to this, when lockdown restrictions started easing, I felt that my manager was fighting our corner to ensure our safety when the "higher-ups" were pressuring us into all coming back full time. This was important as the office and lab spaces we had were very small, so it would have been impossible to be socially distant from each other.
I received ample encouragement to progress my training and career, and felt constantly supported by my team. 
There is also a free shuttle bus for staff members from Sutton train station to the hospital and back.
cons:
Parking can be a nightmare if you're even 2 minutes later than usual. 
Some members of staff weren't very easy to get along with on my team, however I have yet to work in a place where everyone is perfect!

pros:
I've been at EY for nearly 2 years now and I am still so passionate about working here as I have been from my first day.
EY is ahead of the curve for flexible working, promoting diversity and inclusion, celebrating people, and providing training and learning to it's colleagues. I have completed training in Data Visualisation.
I have always felt included at EY, have been myself in the world of work, and have worked collaboratively with colleagues.

EY was leading the way with the coronavirus pandemic and has had really clear plans as to keeping their colleagues and clients safe.
cons:
It is very busy in our team and we're not always given additional hours contributed to our weekly overtime.

Some of the administrative systems are very old.

pros:
Getting to go home and finally leaving
If you want to loose weight work there
cons:
No safety wear issued your dragging out pallets with no safety boots, no googles when using bailer to protect eyes, no proper thick freezer gloves so would get freezer burn on your hands there was a shortage of gloves to wear when putting out stock so I was using gloves from previous employment some staff had paid for their own. Long hours you would be expected to stay over to get stock worked if the day was busy could be 12.30pm or even 4 and 5am then still be expected to do your shift the following day. Heavy work expected to work pallets with unrealistic times a bread pallet would have to be worked is less than 9 mins and 15 mins for the heavier pallets, as a manager you are constantly running around doing the heavy work load while staff are on the tills, micro managed the worse Iv ever experienced assistant store manager constantly on your back, sitting in the office watching staff on cctv then dragging them out the break room on the dot of their break finishing, standing at the tills watching how long it takes for staff to get off the till once’s they have finished with customers, no duty of care to staff, no return to work being done, if you injury yourself your doing your own first aid and no ones recording accidents.
You can’t plan your life as rot-as aren’t done in advance.
No safe and legal standards managers giving keys to under age staff to authorise alcohol sales without then having to come and do it.
Some staff are paid more than the deputy store managers too

pros: The University is relatively high ranked, so looks nice in your CV

Add to this that there is a snobbish professor culture. Situation with diversity and inclusion is very poor. On the whole as everywhere in academia it depends strongly on the group you work in and your professor. But as I said there is overall unhealthy atmosphere. It was recently a wave in media when former North-East students stepped forward and complained about bulling inside the University. It is true what they said. Other groups such as women and people of colour and just not British people also have this problem there.

pros:
- You get a lot of responsibility which makes you learn a lot quick
- There is no (micro)management at all. People trust you entirely in your job.
- Work hours and location are very flexible (even before COVID). Nobody cares if you come in late, or leave early from time to time. It's mainly about your results, people don't mind how you achieve them.
- Frequent team nights and trips with your coworkers are amazing. Going to work quickly feels like hanging out with friends.
cons:
- The autonomous culture is great: you look for your own projects and work on what you think is important. I personally liked it, but for some people this might be confusing and hard.
- The organization is very flat: there's almost no hierarchy. This means you get a lot of decision making power and freedom. But this also means that there is no real way to develop a 'career' within TransferWise. You can only really become a team lead, which is only possible if your lead leaves. Beyond that there's no way to 'climb up the ladder'. The CEO himself said that he 'doesn't want people to come to TransferWise to develop careers'.
- You'll be assigned to an autonomous team, meaning that as an analyst you'll be working with a team of engineers, product manager, designer, etc. There is no functional departments. This has its advantages but it also means you're alone in your role. There's no real senior analysts to learn from.

pros:
-Work is available to those who want the hours. 

-Flexible around commitments as many services operate 24/7.

-The work is challenging due to complex needs service users but at least each day is different. The friendly teams of staff you work with day in day out will make learning the job and also the long days easier. 

-They have one of the most extensive career development pathways in the industry if you are willing to pursue it.
cons:
-As with the wider privatised healthcare/adult care industry employee benefit/conditions have been reduced to the legal minimum.
No sick pay other than SSP, no rising with years of service annual leave, no hourly enhancements for Nightshift, weekends. or overtime. Some services give temporary uplifts for example £1 an hour in times of desperate need but this is rare. In the organisations defence it should be noted the reduced benefits is an industry wide problem directly resulting from post 2010 government spending cuts to NHS and Local Councils, as this is where most revenue comes from. 

-Linked to the first point, some long standing staff are on older contracts and have sick pay entitlement, rising holiday entitlement, and uplifts for Nightshifts, weekends and overtime. While I would never want them stripped of this It is important to note the effect it has on staff morale among the growing proportion of newer staff who do not have these benefits. In effect we are doing the exact same job for less.

pros: Nothing at all in this place
cons:
I worked in 3 Lidl stores. I do not know about Head office or warehouse; I have heard that Head office is much better, and warehouse is just as bad as working in store.
The pay - SAME AS TESCO, SAINSBURYS, ETC and they treat their workers 100x better. The shifts/ hours - Always changing, cannot plan your life, SHIFTS ARE RANDOM, 5-3am one day then 6-11pm the next. Contract hours are rarely stuck to unless you are a manager. For example, someone on 10 hours could do 35 in one week.
The Training – Learn everything on a computer course, colleagues are supposed to show you in real life, they do not, they are busy working understaffed stores. And then managers wonder why you know so little.
The work - Starts at 5AM. Frantically work heavy delivery until store opens without any breakfast or going to the toilet. If you do not complete your delivery in time you will be in trouble because you have to work them in a certain time, there is a lot to do for only a few people. Store opens, you will grab a till, Till 1-3 you will be scanning items as fast as you can through the belt the rest of your shift, at the end of the day YOUR FINGERS WILL BE NUMB AND HURT FROM THE AMOUNT OF TIMES AND SPEED OF GRABBING ITEMS THROUGH THE TILL - NO JOKE HERE. YOU WILL NOT HAVE TIME EVEN TO TALK TO CUSTOMERS BECAUSE OF HOW UNDERSTAFFED YOU ARE. If you are one of the other tills your life will be better as you alternate between shop floor and till. Evening shift starts after midday. If you are on till, then you will be on there until 10pm which is painful. You will speedily do your cleaning up jobs at the end of the day. Unrealistic targets are set for the end of the day, you will half do jobs because one man is not enough to do all of them in one hour. You will go home knackered and wondering why you even go to work. Break will be 30 minutes even on a 12-hour shift, 15 minutes on a 6- hour shift. It is no wonder most store colleagues are young men, they are the only ones who can handle the physical and mental stress. You can forget about any physical exercise you do all your energy will be used up at Lidl!!!
The colleagues - You will be to busy working to get to know anyone, some can be ****. 2 colleagues tried to fight with me, in the middle of store on 2 occasions and another one I knew would shout at customers.
The customers – Usually nice, they get annoyed when you don’t have enough tills, that isn’t your fault - it is the fault of Lidl because they do not employ enough staff. Sometimes you will not have any security so you will watch out for thieves whilst doing your other jobs!!
The managers – wish you had the same ability as 10 workers. Management at head office seem to have no idea about the realities of their stores, or maybe they do and do not care, because they pay homage to those above.
Lidl are a disgrace upon the retail industry, and they should be ashamed for how they treat their store employees. It is disturbing that a western company could operate like this at such a vast scale and get away with it!! Well I guess this is the doomed USA style capitalist ang globalized world we are heading for! Lidl should change the way they run their store operations, but they will not because someone somewhere is getting fat on cash from it. PROSPECTIVE EMPLOYES OF LIDL YOU HAVE BEEN WARNED!!!! As a full time university student I can honestly say Lidl definitely contributed to me loosing my Funded Scholarship, due to the amount of crap I had to deal with this company my grades suffered.
To the company representatives that like to post on all bad reviews, you have either never worked in a lidls supermarket and wouldn't last 5minutes in one, or you are just keeping up the evil lie for your evil company.
Regards, and up yours

pros: clean job and job security
cons: Holiday bookings are a nightmare, have to book a year in advance to guarantee weeks holiday even though your rota only covers 6 months. As you work any 5 from 7 it is possible not to be able to get a full week holiday because you have to book your actual Rota'd days. Hence you might have to take a day off unpaid as holidays are allocated on a percentage of workforce. More and more weekends are creeping into the job but do not receive any extra payments which is making work life balance harder to justify staying in current position . Hence new driver retainment level is very low , the only thing keeping long term servers are their shares and pension scheme . Oh also current pension scheme for new starters is not as same standard as previously . You get text messages interrupting your daily rest period asking for you to come in early because they have a 6 min window delivering to Hermes even though you are travelling over 200 miles, this means you have no time built in your journey for toilet breaks. New starter drivers receive a poorer standard of contract with overtime paid on a weekly basis whereas older contracts receive premium payments on a daily basis.

pros: None, the only pro I could say there was for the shop I worked in was that there was a Christmas meal that was paid for and a buffet on Black Friday, bearing in mind that you would have to work at least 13 hours on that day we less than 20 minutes of break time as you wouldn’t have time to have anything longer and your standard half an hour lunch wasn’t allowed.
cons:
Where do I start...

Wages - shocking wages. I was paid by the hour and from the time I started working till my last day I only had an increase of about £1 in three years.

My second point, Black Friday week / Black Friday. You are worked to death, even on the customer service desk, where I worked. Both of the Black Fridays I worked whilst with Curry’s, I worked at least 13 hours on these days. 

Work promotions do not exist if you are a customer service rep in stores. The only way you can possibly be promoted into a higher position such as a team leader or manager, was to go into a sales role which meant you would be put under stupid pressure to hit targets which were sometimes if not a lot of the time, impossible to hit and you were also at the bottom of the pile for any promotion even if you were there for a good few years like me. 

I was stuck in a store with colleagues who could not give a damn about working there. With me being on the customer service desk, any issue, no matter how small, they would push on me and my colleagues to deal with, even if it was a case of they messed up on a sale or messed up on something else, we were expected to sort it out. 

Management only cared about the sale staff and that is saying something as they didn’t really care a lot about them either. 

The new holiday/roster system that came in before I left was shocking...even the old system of just printed out rosters on a wall was bad but this was worse. There was a period where I was rostered to work 12 days in a row. When I raised this with my manager, he didn’t care. He gave me 3 days off at the end but would not even toy wi try the idea of breaking my working days up and just had no interest at all. I saw people coming and going from their holidays and weekends and days off whilst I was still working. My 9th day went passed, then my 10th and 11th and finally my 12th with no break in between. This was me working 9 hours a day also with 2 hours of travelling to and from work.

Holidays, you are banned from putting in any holiday requests at all from the middle of November until the middle of January as this is a busy period. Only exceptional circumstances would allow for you to be on holiday. Even students who went home for Christmas would be expected to transfer to another store for how ever many weeks. 

I was expected to take abuse from customers every single day for stuff that was not my fault or even the companies fault yet i explained how we would move forward, a manager would get involved and tell them the complete opposite, undermining what I said making me feel like an idiot.

No architects. All new requirements are badly considered and communicated,

Great practical care of employees wellbeing throughout lockdown.

If you are interested in markets then it's a really interesting and rewarding role with great opportunities to progress and develop.

Team and management does a good job of including junior employees in feeling they are a part of the team's success and are rewarded accordingly. Individual successes and efforts are always recognised and encouraged.
cons: Moving in the right direction but more schemes for inter-office collaboration and socialising at all levels would be great (appreciate it's been difficult in 2020).

Lots of Razor on the front end - typical microsoft development house with lots of full stack developers (which are actually back end C#.NET devs that think they know a lot about front end but end up using tables and floats to build layouts in 2021).
Oh and you have to be on call/do overtime

pros:
Interesting projects
London offices are nice and in good locations
Attracts some really good people
cons:
Awful culture, the stereotype of big 4 consultants talking rather than doing is true.
People on the career ladder only seem to care about money. Every action is targeted towards having highlights to say at end of year review in order to justify a big bonus or promotion.
Promotion is primarily based on time served and making friends with those above you.
Short term gain is put above long term gain. A quick decision is better than the right decision.
I saw and heard some very dubious actions, at best they were unethical, some possibly illegal.
They also don’t like junior staff challenging senior staff, it’s viewed as being “difficult” and “not collaborative”.
Very hierarchical, people like to appear senior so will try to keep hierarchical structures so they can say they had people report to them.
A lot of managers couldn’t manage and didn’t have a clue what they were doing. The resulting chaos usually results in junior staff working on stuff that isn’t necessary and doing lots of overtime.
There is surprisingly little processes and procedures.  How something gets done or what decisions gets made is largely up to whoever is on the job.
Pay is very asymmetrical, partners are on ridiculous salaries while those at the bottom can be quite low. Feel that senior people justify this as “time severed” and now they can get the rewards.

I witnessed no accommodations being given to a member of staff with disabilities - which is illegal.
