pros: Arguably one of the best office buildings in London. Free snacks in the pantry. Travel in business class and staying at five star hotels is company policy. Great training at the beginning of your career. Pay is decent to start but can stagnate. Huge Summer party. Well recognised brand for your CV.
cons:
To understand Bloomberg’s culture, you need to understand Bloomberg’s business and operating model. Bloomberg is a monopoly in financial markets with flash marketing and thought leadership. The company is like an old oak tree, so far engrained into every fibre of the market, that it is impossible to rip out. Their monopoly is on the community (mainly the IB chat), which gives them an advantage over competitors, as clients trade on their platform and consume data. The reality is ‘The Terminal’ is an overpriced piece of Teletext. Much of what you get, is already available for free online, or for very little subscription cost, and most of the data is not even theirs; it is aggregated from other vendors. Most clients know this, but there is nothing they can do. If you are a bank – you make markets over Bloomberg, it’s that simple. Then every two years your 5% price increase letter arrives, leaving you wondering what exactly you are paying for. 

Management is a cult-like mafia. The company is still private and 84% owned by Mike Bloomberg himself. Loyalty to the cult is rewarded above all else. It is not a place where your ideas are welcome. There is a reason most of the Management are Bloomberg veterans (10+ years) and they do not hire external Sales people – toe the line or get out. 

Sales, or what they call ‘Sales’, is more like customer success indirect selling. The company operates a high touch model, with demanding quantitative targets; constantly bombarding clients with marketing spam, meetings etc. Reps become resourceful and cheat the system to keep Managers happy. Remuneration is not clear, hitting your targets doesn’t mean a pay check. Expect better bonuses in the back office of a bank, with the millions you sold being syphoned off to Bloomberg Philanthropies, or Mike’s $1bn vanity project i.e. his 2020 Presidential bid. 

Lastly, micromanagement, which is getting worse, due to COVID. Expect to be monitored on how many emails, calls, visits, demos, adoption of certain client criteria etc. The system is broken because too many people cheat the metrics and it becomes a dull existence constantly finding ways to keep up. They will even show the time you enter and leave the office, visible to all employees within the company. Everything is quantified and you are stacked against your peers, with year-end evaluations focusing on where you sit on the bell curve.

pros:
Overall compensation
Top tech kit
Some areas are very promising
cons:
When joining, I picked Shops because it was a promising project, but after I made my decision, it was clear that the Org was notoriously disorganised. The project has lost most of its key personnel because the Director for Product was unable to give a clear direction, and censored all the reasonable ideas. My manager was inexperienced and refused to hear any suggestion that I made. It felt really demoralising and frustrating. I reached out to other managers, friends from previous job who agreed that it was frustrating… but that’s it.
– I agree, this is a horrible situation.
– What can I do about it?
– I don’t know…
– Wait a year, so I can change teams?
– Maybe. That was changed to 18 months though.

All three of the Org, the project and my manager had "the worst Pulse rating in the history of the company" at their level, according to people who had been at Facebook longer. No one reached out.

Several key stakeholders left, notably one senior Data engineer. I offered to take over some of their workload because I knew how and I badly needed data to do my own work. That was yet another suggestion that my manager shut down.

It got tiring really fast.

pros:
You work the hours in your contract - on most days you will finish at 5 and you don’t need to worry about work until the next day.

It is a very inclusive culture, everyone is very nice and chatty. Great environment to work in.

There are always leads/people around willing to help if you find something hard or come across something you haven’t dealt with before.

Once you are in there are a lot of places throughout the civil service you can apply internally for.
cons:
It is not a meritocracy. If you work twice as hard as the next person, they will say thank you. Your career won’t benefit.

The application process into the job and to internally apply for jobs is terrible. They clearly explain what they are looking for and then routinely pass over people who are perfect for the job/have been doing it on temporary promotion for years for someone with no experience.

pros: Stacking selves and scanning items doesn't require much thought.
cons: Managers will try guilt trip you into working faster even if you are new to the store because "Aldi is efficient and about pace". Management will expect you to pick up overtime even if you cannot do it. Many of the managers have a power trip and believe that you have to do all the leg work and will not assist you. They believe getting paid £1 more than minimum wage is enough of a reason to pester you about your work pace even if you are already working as fast as you can. A few members of staff openly expressed derogatory, racist and homophobic slurs and views, when the management were told, no action was taken.

pros: The lovely team that I worked with made it bearable, and (some) helpful assistant management. They are quick to offer development opportunities e.g management training. Good overall ethos, values and culture portrayed by the company that doesn't seem to be followed through in practice by the management of restaurants.
cons: General Manager was not a people person. Hired far too many young (15/16/17 year old) waitresses and expected far too much from them, pushed many to tears. It was an exhausting job and everybody ended up working a lot of overtime, I often worked until the early hours of the morning, due to shortage of staff being put on late night closes. A lot of issues with staff and rotas. They would keep you in the staff room on standby, and wouldn't let you clock in or be paid for your time, if you turned up to your shift and the restaurant wasn't busy enough to justify the number of staff.

pros: Good salary and benefits, interesting work, motivated and talented staff
cons: Big corpration means sometimes admin gets in the way

pros:
- The mission to bring affordable healthcare to people is, at the end of the day, one of the main benefits.
- Opportunity to work with some great people, although the good ones are leaving in droves for a long time now which has become very demoralizing.
- Opportunity to work on interesting projects in an interesting industry.
cons:
- Career progression is non-existent with both managers and HR to blame. HR constantly changes the framework every year and managers promote based on unfair criteria such as how friendly you are with them. Forget about salary increase, even for inflation, you will be served every fairy tale in the world to explain why that's not possible.
- The business changes directions every month or so which is not atypical for a startup, however, due to heavy regulations in the industry this makes everything move extremely slowly at ground level and you're stuck in a limbo state not being able to focus on actual work towards a goal.
- Benefits disappear suddenly such as the employee discount scheme, and engineers are provided with low specced laptops from three years ago to work on even though this is a unicorn.
- Heavy regulation impedes a lot of the engineering progress and results in a mess of useless processes to make a few people feel safe.

There is more and a great deal more has already been said in other reviews on the negative side, some bits exaggerated, some bits just not happening in my team, but at the moment the cons objectively outweigh the pros by a significant margin, otherwise there wouldn't be a big number of talented people jumping ship.

You get to see a lot of the UK.

pros: Tends to pay well to keep you from leaving for a better company
cons:
Long hours , pretend culture of work life balance being important , not the case especially if your a working parent . Hours are always long and persistent last minute deadlines given from head office meaning hours of work are ridiculous and constant email checking is the only way to operate effectively thus work life balance doesn’t exist. Company pretends to operate a culture where development is key and will fund exams but that’s as far as the support goes , time off for study or a mentor isn’t discussed or offered at all. 
In all just a large corporate company that says all the right things on the tin to tick boxes and look like a good place to work however actually working for them is completely the opposite.

pros: Well organised WFH, good communication from Management, good benefit package, generally nice and dedicated colleagues, interesting work and lots going on.
cons: There is a huge emphasis on culture and colleague wellbeing. However, it often feels that these are just glossy words. In practice, the workload/pressure on employees to deliver is huge, with long hours and very heavy workload. For Sage to really "do the right thing" (company's motto), successfully create a supportive culture and have happy employees, Management need to listen more carefully, and allocate adequate resources to support overworked teams and avoid burnouts. Granted lots of efforts have been made, but there's still a long way to go.
